item.title: One-Child Rule Is Gone in China, but Scars Will Linger
item.description: Through forced sterilizations and abortions, the killing of infants and the sale of children, the decades-old policy touched families across China.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.media:credit: Mimi Miranda Kuo for The New York Times
item.media:description: An abortion clinic in eastern China. Human rights abuses tied to the one-child rule included forced sterilizations and abortions.

item.title: Obama to Send Special Operations Forces to Help Fight ISIS in Syria
item.description: The White House announced on Friday that a small number of Special Operations troops would be deployed to Kurdish-controlled territory in northern Syria.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER and PETER BAKER

item.title: Indonesia’s Forest Fires Take Toll on Wildlife, Big and Small
item.description: Scientists and environmentalists can only speculate about the extent of the damage to the animals, but early signs are not promising.
item.dc:creator: JOE COCHRANE
item.media:description: An orangutan at a rehabilitation center in Central Kalimantan Province, Indonesia. A broad spectrum of wildlife, including elephants, birds and snakes, has been severely affected by the fires, scientists say.

item.title: Syrian Government Attacks Rebel-Held Suburb, Killing 40, Activists Say
item.description: The attack on Douma, a suburb of Damascus, involved ground shelling as well as airstrikes, an opposition activist said. The shells hit an open-air market.
item.dc:creator: HWAIDA SAAD and KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Deso Dogg, Ex-Rapper Who Joined ISIS, Is Killed by U.S. Airstrike
item.description: The Pentagon confirmed that an Oct. 16 strike killed Denis Cuspert, better known as Deso Dogg, who had been designated a “global terrorist.”
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINE HAUSER
item.media:description: Denis Cuspert, a former rapper from Germany, in Berlin in 2011.

item.title: U.N. Urges Inquiry Into Attack on Cambodian Opposition Lawmakers
item.description: The body was reacting to an episode in which a crowd of around 2,000 demonstrators dragged the two from their car and beat them as the police reportedly looked on.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Roman Polanski Won’t Be Expedited After Polish Court Rejects U.S. Request
item.description: A judge ruled that turning Mr. Polanski over would be an “obviously unlawful” deprivation of liberty for the filmmaker, who is wanted on a 1977 conviction for having sex with a 13-year-old.
item.dc:creator: MICHAL KOLANKO and MICHAEL CIEPLY
item.media:description: The Polish filmmaker Roman Polanski, right, with his lawyer Jerzy Stachowicz in court last month in Krakow, Poland.

item.title: Channel Tunnel Migrant Emerges at Center of Asylum Debate
item.description: Human rights groups say Abdul Rahman Haroun, incarcerated for nearly three months, is a scapegoat at a time when immigrants are not welcome in Britain.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: Thousands of migrants have been scaling fences and fleeing the police as they try to enter the Channel Tunnel.

item.title: Chinese Tycoon Wang Jianlin Defends Xi’s Relatives, and Himself, on Business Deal
item.description: Mr. Wang said President Xi Jinping’s relatives had sold their shares in his company two months before its initial public offering, missing out on a “fortune” in capital gains.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: Wang Jianlin, the chairman of Dalian Wanda Commercial Properties.

item.title: Shaker Aamer Is Released From Guantánamo Prison After 13 Years
item.description: Mr. Aamer, a Saudi citizen and British resident whose detention drew protests from human rights advocates and rock stars, was flown to London.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: CHARLIE SAVAGE and STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:credit: Reprieve UK, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Shaker Aamer, a Saudi citizen and British resident, was held at the Guantánamo Bay prison in Cuba for more than 13 years.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Mei Fong on the Impact of China’s ‘One Child’ Policy
item.description: Ms. Fong, a former reporter for The Wall Street Journal in China, discusses how the birth restrictions reshaped Chinese society, perhaps irreversibly.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: The Saturday Profile: An Arab, Muslim, and Israeli Officer at the Center of a Storm
item.description: Police work has been a calling for Superintendent Luba Samri since she joined the force, and she is at the crossroads of competing loyalties and emotions.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:credit: Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Superintendent Luba Samri with members of a SWAT team at Police Headquarters in Jerusalem.

item.title: Bangladesh Pushes Back as Warnings of ISIS Expansion Gather Steam
item.description: The disconnect between the country and foreign intelligence agencies could complicate efforts to prevent the spread of global terrorism in South Asia.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY
item.media:description: The disconnect between Bangladesh and foreign intelligence agencies has confused Bangladeshis and foreigners alike, and could complicate anti-terrorism efforts.

item.title: Greek Premier Condemns Europe’s Response to Migrant Crisis
item.description: Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras railed against other leaders for not providing a safe alternative for the thousands trying to reach the Continent in rickety boats across treacherous seas.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: Volunteers and residents helped refugees disembark from a sunken boat in Lesbos, Greece, on Friday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Lawyer Casts Skeptical Eye on Family-Planning Changes
item.description: Wu Youshui, a lawyer, expects the system to continue to exercise a hold over citizens’ reproductive health.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Outside a children's hospital in Beijing on Friday. Local governments collect billions of dollars each year from fines levied on families having more than one child.

item.title: In Victory for Philippines, Hague Court to Hear Dispute Over South China Sea
item.description: The case is being closely watched by the United States and other Asian nations that are claimants in the strategic waterway.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ
item.media:credit: Department of Foreign Affairs/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: An aerial view of the Chinese-held Johnson South Reef, which is also claimed by the Philippines and Vietnam, in the South China Sea last year.

item.title: North Korea to Hold Convention for Workers’ Party
item.description: The party’s Politburo said the meeting was needed to strengthen the party’s role under the country’s leader, state news media said.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: A military parade in North Korea this month celebrating the 70th anniversary of the country's ruling Workers' Party.

item.title: China Will Feel One-Child Policy’s Effects for Decades, Experts Say
item.description: Having one child has become the social norm in China, demographers say, so allowing two children per couple will have a limited impact.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK
item.media:description: A woman carrying a child in a traditional basket on the outskirts of Chongqing, China, in 2013.

item.title: World Briefing: South Korea: Russian Jets Approach U.S. Carrier
item.description: The nuclear-powered aircraft carrier Ronald Reagan was taking part in a military exercise with South Korea when a pair of Russian bombers flew within one nautical mile of the ship.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW ROSENBERG

item.title: Open Source: As More Children Drown, Volunteers on Lesbos Say Rescues Are Left Largely to Them
item.description: Volunteers on the Greek island of Lesbos lashed out at European governments and aid organizations, saying they are allowing migrants to suffer and die.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: ROBERT MACKEY
